meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Rebels' Fiery Roadblocks Limit Access to Beirut Burning tires blocked a street south of Beirut as supporters of Hezbollah clashed with backers of the government, raising fears of open sectarian conflict. At least three people died and 100 were injured throughout Lebanon in violence called the worst since Hezbollah began demanding more political power last year.
PAGE A6
Diners as Devotees In many of today's upscale restaurants there is an unsettling meeting of self-regarding restaurateurs and self-effacing diners who are seen as lucky to be customers.
PAGE F1
In Greenwich Village, the Waverly Inn is a charming but clubby restaurant co-owned by Graydon Carter of Vanity Fair. Review by Frank Bruni.
PAGE F9
And the Winner Might Be ''Dreamgirls'' got the most Oscar nods, yet the best picture nominees are ''Babel,'' ''The Departed,'' ''Letters From Iwo Jima,'' ''Little Miss Sunshine'' and ''The Queen.''
PAGE E1
Iraq 'Dire,' U.S. General Says Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus, the president's new choice as the top commander in Iraq, told a Senate committee that the situation in Iraq was ''dire'' but not hopeless.
PAGE A9
E. Howard Hunt Dies The ex-C.I.A. agent who as the White House's master of dirty tricks bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought down Richard M. Nixon was 88.
PAGE C13

Rebels' Fiery Roadblocks Limit Access to Beirut Burning tires blocked a street south of Beirut as supporters of Hezbollah clashed with backers of the government, raising fears of open sectarian conflict. At least three people died and 100 were injured throughout Lebanon in violence called the worst since Hezbollah began demanding more political power last year.
PAGE A6
Diners as Devotees In many of today's upscale restaurants there is an unsettling meeting of self-regarding restaurateurs and self-effacing diners who are seen as lucky to be customers.
PAGE F1
In Greenwich Village, the Waverly Inn is a charming but clubby restaurant co-owned by Graydon Carter of Vanity Fair. Review by Frank Bruni.
PAGE F9
And the Winner Might Be ''Dreamgirls'' got the most Oscar nods, yet the best picture nominees are ''Babel,'' ''The Departed,'' ''Letters From Iwo Jima,'' ''Little Miss Sunshine'' and ''The Queen.''
PAGE E1
Iraq 'Dire,' U.S. General Says Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus, the president's new choice as the top commander in Iraq, told a Senate committee that the situation in Iraq was ''dire'' but not hopeless.
PAGE A9
E. Howard Hunt Dies The ex-C.I.A. agent who as the White House's master of dirty tricks bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought down Richard M. Nixon was 88.
PAGE C13
